column3: address nits and rebased onto master
utACK 803027d.

Looks good to me.

Another way to do this would be to add a second node to this test with `-mempoolreplacement=0`, and then in `test_simple_doublespend()` check that `self.nodes[0]` accepts the replacement and `self.nodes[1]` rejects it. There are a couple of advantages to doing it in that way:

- doesn't introduce delay in stop-starting the node (multiple nodes are started in parallel)
> Thoughts?\n\n@jnewbery LGTM.

updated the test thanks to @jnewbery 's suggestion.\n\nOne thing I wasn't sure of was a fast way of checking for mempool rejection at the p2p layer. The last check I'm doing could definitely be racy, but I can't call self.sync_all() since the mempools are bound to diverge.
utACK 1088b5322
```python\nself.restart_node(0, ["-mempoolreplacement=0"])\n```

```python
self.restart_node(0)
```
Note that it will use `self.extra_args[0]` by default.
Nit, remove `()`?
:+1: assert is a statement, not a function
is this restart necessary?
figured people wouldn't want it disabled for subsequent tests?
Makes sense, although a stop-start adds a few seconds to the test runtime.
@jnewbery not with #11006.
Could just say "this should be the last test to avoid another restart" or something.

@jnewbery stop/start/restart could be deferred to the point they are needed unless a *flush* option is set. For instance:
```python
start_node(0)
stop_node(0)
```
would do nothing. This way tests could be more isolated, less dependable of previous tests.
@promag - indeed. I've already concept ACK'ed that. I think it was waiting on input from Wlad?\n\n@instagibbs - comment looks good.

@promag interesting suggestion. I like the fact that it would make tests more isolated, but I don't like that it takes control of the nodes away from the test-writer. At the moment our tests are all very imperative, and this would be a slight departure from that model.\n\nIt's an interesting thought, but one that should be discussed in a separate issue or PR I think.
> separate issue or PR I think.\n\nSure! Just a thought.
ubernit: I think this comment could be clearer by adding "when transaction replacement is disabled"\n\nultranit: swap order with the line below, so you send to node[0] then node[1]
